title: 111_hr1846
content: The Act may be cited as the "Consumer Lending Education And Reform Act" and the "C.L.E.A.R. Act". It provides protections for consumers. The "Consumer Lending Education And Reform Act" (C.L.E.A.R. Act) introduces new protections for consumers under the Truth in Lending Act. It includes definitions for terms like affiliate, electronic signature, and extended payment plan. The Act also defines "home state" for regulatory purposes. The "Consumer Lending Education And Reform Act" (C.L.E.A.R. Act) defines terms like "home state" as the state where a creditor's primary office is located and "interest and fees" as charges imposed by the creditor as part of credit extension, excluding default charges. The term 'interest and fees' excludes charges for defaults, delinquencies, or similar occurrences, and charges for unavailable funds to pay items to the creditor. Charges must not exceed $25 or the amount charged by the creditor's financial institution, and can only be imposed once per item or authorization. A payday loan is a closed-end credit transaction with a term of 7 to 90 days, not exceeding $2,000, and with a finance charge exceeding 36% APR. The consumer receives funds and provides a payment instrument to the creditor simultaneously. Loan stores are locations where payday loan applications are received or proceeds are disbursed. The payday lender provides funds to the consumer and agrees not to deposit the payment instrument for more than 1 day. Refinancing involves using the proceeds of one payday loan to pay off any amount due to the creditor. Consumer protections include an interest and fee cap for payday lenders. A payday lender is restricted from charging consumers more than 15 cents for every dollar loaned in interest and fees. Refinancing limits are set at 15 cents for the 1st refinancing and 10 cents for the 2nd refinancing of the original loan amount. A payday lender is prohibited from charging consumers more than 15 cents for every dollar loaned in interest and fees, with refinancing limits set at 15 cents for the 1st refinancing and 10 cents for the 2nd refinancing of the original loan amount. Mandatory disclosures are required before making or refinancing a payday loan, including a written loan agreement with clear terms, total cost of fees, creditor information, and consumer payment obligations. The payday loan agreement must include the creditor's contact information, a warning that the loan is for short-term needs only, and information on credit counseling options. Contact an approved counselor near you by calling the National Foundation for Credit Counseling at 1-800-388-2227. No criminal prosecution or security interest can be pursued for this loan. Additional public disclosures are required for payday lenders, including a warning that the loan is not for long-term financial needs. The payday loan should only be used for short-term cash needs. Contact an approved credit counseling agency for assistance. No criminal prosecution or security interest can be pursued for this loan. A payday lender must obtain and file a surety bond in specific amounts based on the number of loan stores operated and whether loans are offered over the Internet. The bond amount ranges from $100,000 to $1,000,000, or as required by state law. A payday lender must file a surety bond with the State attorney general in their home state. Lenders and affiliates with the same home state can aggregate loan stores to determine the bond amount. A lender must offer an extended payment plan if a consumer notifies them of inability to repay before the loan's due date. A payday lender must offer an extended payment plan to consumers who notify them of inability to repay before the loan's due date. The lender cannot engage in collection activities during the extended payment plan period. Refinancing of payday loans is limited to not less than 7 days, not more than 2 consecutive times, and must involve a new agreement signed by both parties. Interest and fees on refinancing cannot exceed the permitted amount. In connection with refinancing exceeding permitted amount under section 129B, technical amendments are made to Truth in Lending Act. Payday loans subject to section 129B are exempt from state laws requiring minimum loan terms. In connection with refinancing exceeding permitted amount under section 129B of the Truth in Lending Act, payday loans are exempt from state laws regulating loan terms, refinancing, payment plans, interest rates, and fees. States can enforce section 129B requirements. "129A. Fiduciary duty of servicers of pooled residential mortgages. 129B. Protections for consumers."
